intro: Brassica campestris var. toria, commonly known as field mustard, is an annual herbaceous plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, characterized by its cross-shaped flowers and glucosinolate compounds. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–100 cm, with pinnately lobed leaves and yellow flowers that bloom in early summer. It is often found in disturbed soils, roadsides, and agricultural fields, and is known for its peppery flavor when the leaves are harvested. This species is also an important host plant for various pests and is used in some traditional medicinal practices.
